Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Nanostructured Ceramics Membranes for Redox Flow Batteries with Superior Performance and Low Cost
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project seeks to develop a novel low-cost molecular filter for use in harsh environments. This is accomplished using commodity silica gel, commonly found as a desiccant in food packing, whose pores can be made to be only a few molecules wide. Accurate tuning of the size and shape of the silica gel pores enables certain molecules to pass through while others are block from passing. One promising application for these molecular filters is their use in grid-scale energy storage. Flow batteries have the ability to store city-sized quantities of renewable energy. However, they require the use of expensive molecular filters that are not easily replaced due to the harsh battery environments. The low-cost filters developed during this SBIR Phase I project have the potential to reduce the cost of flow batteries by as much as 30%. Lower cost grid-scale storage means that more renewable energy generation (e.g., solar & wind) can be added without overwhelming the grid. Low cost molecular filter also have commercial upside with the potential to capture a $1.3 billion dollar market. Because of this, this project is expected to generate nearly 20 jobs and $79 million dollars in tax revenue over the next 5 years.


This SBIR Phase 1 Project is developing a molecularly selective sol-gel ceramic membrane that does not require calcination or high polymer loading but also does not fracture during compression in stack applications (e.g., fuel cells and flow batteries). This is accomplished by decoupling the selective region from the region of the membrane being compresses by the stack. These membranes will be utilized to improve the performance and reduce the costs of all-vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFB). These membranes require selective transport of hydronium ions but not vanadium ions. Size exclusion membranes must therefore have tight control over the pore size and size distribution, shape and network structure in order to selectively transport ions. Towards this end, sol-gel processing and surface chemistry modification will be utilized to maximize proton conductivity and limit vanadium ion permeability. Optimized membrane formulations must also have excellent chemical and mechanical stability; showing no degradation after hundreds of VRFB cycles. Finally, membranes must be scaled from lab size (1 cm2) to commercial size (630 cm2) while maintaining performance uniformity. The low-cost membranes developed during this SBIR Phase I project have the potential to reduce the cost of VRFBs by as much as 30%. Lower cost grid-scale storage means that more renewable energy generation (e.g., solar & wind) can be added without overwhelming the grid.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This successful SBIR Phase I project developed a proof-of-concept molecular filter for use in harsh environments that is 10X less expensive to manufacture than the current state-of-the-art. This was accomplished by using silica gel, the desiccant material found in the bottom of a shoebox or beef jerky package. Silica gel is effective at keeping products dry because it has molecule size pores that can absorb water. This project developed a way make a thin sheet of silica gel and then control the size of those small pores in order to filter molecules. Silica is also the primary component of glass, which makes it incredibly resistant to harsh chemicals that can degrade other molecular filters made from specialty plastics.

The accomplished goals of this project were to 1) be able to control the pore size and demonstrate that it could selectively filter certain molecules present in batteries, 2) show the new silica filters could be optimized to perform as well as specialty plastic filters while maintaining a 10X cost reduction, 3) prove that the filters would not degrade under extremely harsh conditions and 4) demonstrate that the filters could be made at commercially relevant sizes. These completed goals demonstrated the significant promise of this innovation to address long standing problems with specialty plastic filters.

Specialty plastic filters, also called ion exchange membranes, represent a $2.3 billion market that is rapidly growing. However, the intrinsically high cost of production and poor performance often reduces the commercial viability of new technologies that rely on these filters. This is because specialty plastic filters often account for 20 – 70% of the cost of a final product. Some of the products that incorporate and rely on these filters include:

-      Redox flow batteries that can store city size quantities of energy but are still much more expensive than lithium ion

-      Electrodialysis water filtration that requires 30% less energy to purify salt water but is more expensive that reverse osmosis

-      Hydrogen fuel cells that have 150x the energy density of lithium ion batteries but remain expensive to produce

-      Pharmaceutical production processes that have outlandish costs that are passed along to consumers

The proof-of-concept silica filters developed in this project could radically lower the costs and improve the performance of these technologies such that they become less expensive than their inferior competitors that are already on the market. This would in-turn create a much larger market for this type of molecular filter and create a positive feedback loop in which all technologies are less expensive to produce because of economies of scale. Ultimately, this innovation creates jobs and new sources of tax revenue for the United States.
